nodes.text: State-level economic policy uncertainty (EPU) can be quantified using local newspaper archives and these state-level EPU measures are meaningful for studying drivers and economic consequences of policy uncertainty within and across U.S. states
Data source: digital archives of about 3,500 local newspapers, median 49 papers per state-month, sample varies by state (some back to 1985, all states since 2006); indexes updated publicly

Index construction: for each state and month construct three normalized monthly indexes - EPU-S (state/local sources), EPU-N (national/international sources), and composite EPU-C - by flagging articles containing Economy, Uncertainty, and policy term sets tailored for state vs national and normalizing by a 2006-2019 baseline

Descriptive evidence: decomposition shows substantial share of EPU-C articles concern state/local policy (pre-COVID: national-only ~50%, state-only ~30%, both ~20%; March 2020-June 2021: national-only 38%, state-only 40%, both 22%), and cross-state variation in the EPU-S/EPU-N ratio is large

Elections raise state-level policy uncertainty: presidential elections raise EPU-N (about 33 log points on average); gubernatorial elections raise EPU-S more strongly; close elections (vote margin <4%) produce substantially larger increases (close presidential ~60% increase in EPU-N; close gubernatorial ~35% increase in EPU-S)

National/international events raise EPU-N widely: 9-11, 2011 debt-ceiling crisis, Brexit referendum, 2016 presidential election surprise, and federal shutdowns produced large increases in EPU-N across most states (median one-month jumps often tens of log points)

State-specific episodes raise EPU-S: examples include California electricity crisis and 2003 gubernatorial recall, Kansas 2012 tax experiment, Hurricane Katrina in Louisiana, and Michigan exposure during the Great Recession, demonstrating diverse state drivers of uncertainty

Empirical strategy for causal dynamics: fit panel VARs to monthly state-level ln(EPU-C) and economic activity (unemployment rate or log employment) with six lags, state fixed effects, and Cholesky identification (alternate orderings and filters tested); estimation uses balanced panel of 44 states (2001-2019) to avoid COVID-era anomalies

VAR results: upward own-state EPU-C shocks foreshadow weaker economic performance in the stateâ€”higher unemployment and lower employment with hump-shaped responses peaking around one year (example: Hamilton-filtered peak unemployment response ~0.10 percentage points to a one standard deviation ln(EPU-C) shock)

Spatial spillovers: extending VARs to include a population-weighted border-state EPU measure shows that upward EPU shocks in neighboring states negatively affect own-state unemployment; own and border shocks of equal size have similar peak effects

Pandemic-era shift in sources: COVID-19 produced huge increases in EPU; the relative importance shifted toward state/local sources after February 2020 (cross-state average EPU-S/EPU-N rose from 0.65 pre-pandemic to 1.1 from March 2020 to June 2021)

Pandemic heterogeneity and outcomes: cross-state regression evidence shows COVID death rates per capita do not predict EPU rises, but stricter government lockdowns (indexed from shelter-in-place, business, restaurant, school closure orders) predict larger increases in EPU and larger increases in unemployment; conditional on death rates, stricter lockdown stringency associated with unemployment increases of order 0.6-1.0 percentage points across quarters

Conclusion: state-level newspaper-based EPU indexes (EPU-S, EPU-N, EPU-C) are valuable tools that reveal distinct drivers of uncertainty across states and time, help estimate economic effects of uncertainty and policy (including spillovers), and enable research on elections, lockdowns, and subnational policy

Limitation: coverage and signal-to-noise vary across states and time (smaller states and earlier sample periods have fewer newspapers and noisier EPU series), which may attenuate estimated effects and motivate robustness checks using larger states and alternative filters
